awd_titl_txt: Bridge to the Doctorate at UMCP, 2012-2014
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
The Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Program is committed to strengthening the linkage between the undergraduate and doctoral degree by transitioning previous LSAMP graduates to Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) graduate programs. During the 2012-2014 academic years, 13 LSAMP alumni were awarded the BD fellowship to pursue graduate study at the University of Maryland College Park (UMD); of which two fellows were awarded for only one year. The goal of the BD program is to increase the number of LSAMP alumni who go on to earn doctoral degrees and choose careers in STEM fields, especially the professoriate.

Intellectual Merit: The BD activity provided a cohort of 12 students who have participated in LSAMP Programs as undergraduates, the opportunity to receive substantial funding and other critical support to successfully pursue graduate degrees in diverse STEM fields at one of the nation’s top research universities. BD students conducted cutting-edge research with top research scientists on the UMD campus and at national laboratories located in close proximity to the university. Other research and education activities in which the Fellows engaged in were:

  • BD Monthly Community Meetings
  • BD Advising, Counseling and Follow-up
  • Scientific and Professional Conferences
  • LSAMP BD National meeting
  • Support of the UMD LSAMP Undergraduate Research Symposium
  • UMD Professional and Personal Development Seminars

Below were other components of the BD Program:

BD Project Directors-Faculty Advisors/Graduate Program Staff Partnership. The BD Project Directors formed partnerships with the academic departments of the BD Fellows to build a stronger connection between the BD program and the academic units.

Funding Commitments Post-BD. In Fall 2012, the Project Directors received written confirmation from each academic department of the 2012-2014 BD Fellows committing funding for the students once BD ended. Additonally, the UMD Graduate School provided tuition remission to supplement the BD awards in the cases where a Fellow's tuition need exceeded the BD award.

BD Program Evaluation. An evaluation of the 2012-14 BD cohort was conducted by an external evaluator. The overall goal of the evaluation was to examine the experiences of current BD fellowship participants to understand the factors that contribute to the success of the students as well as those that impede their progress. Some of these themes that emerged include 1) science predisposition, 2) points of transition, 3) supporting/mentoring, 4) presence of a "like-type" community and 5) program components. Some new findings also emerged such as the need for additional study skills and time managment workshops as well as workshops that connect Fellows to STEM industry professionals. Based on the findings of this exploratory study, eight recommendations were offered to assist the BD program with assessing the needs of the students and the program’s initiatives for next year.  

BD Information Dissemination. During the 2012-2014 project, the BD Project Directors disseminated information on the BD Program on the LSAMP website and the BD Cohort listerv.

Broader Impacts: Many LSAMP students are members of groups that traditionally have been underrepresented in STEM fields. This BD activity increased the number of such students in the pipeline to earn doctoral degrees in these fields. Additionally, activities were planned to provide the participants with information about a variety of STEM caree...
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Bridge to the Doctorate (BD) Program  is committed to strengthening the linkage between the undergraduate and  doctoral degree by transitioning previous LSAMP graduates to Science,  Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) graduate programs.  During the 2012-2014 academic years, 13 LSAMP alumni were awarded the BD fellowship to pursue graduate study at the University of Maryland  College Park (UMD); of which two fellows were awarded for only one year. The goal of the BD program is to increase the number  of LSAMP alumni who go on to earn doctoral degrees and choose careers  in STEM fields, especially the professoriate.

Intellectual Merit: The BD activity provided a  cohort of 12 students who have participated in LSAMP Programs as  undergraduates, the opportunity to receive substantial funding and other  critical support to successfully pursue graduate degrees in diverse  STEM fields at one of the nationÆs top research universities. BD  students conducted cutting-edge research with top research scientists  on the UMD campus and at national laboratories located in close  proximity to the university. Other research and education activities in which the Fellows engaged in were:

BD Monthly Community Meetings 
BD Advising, Counseling and Follow-up
Scientific and Professional Conferences 
LSAMP BD National meeting
Support of the UMD LSAMP Undergraduate Research Symposium 
UMD Professional and Personal Development Seminars


Below were other components of the BD Program:

BD Project Directors-Faculty Advisors/Graduate Program Staff Partnership. The  BD Project Directors formed partnerships with the academic departments  of the BD Fellows to build a stronger connection between the BD program  and the academic units.

Funding Commitments Post-BD. In Fall 2012, the Project Directors received written confirmation from  each academic department of the 2012-2014 BD Fellows committing funding  for the students once BD ended. Additonally, the UMD Graduate School provided tuition remission to supplement the BD awards in the cases where a Fellow's tuition need exceeded the BD award.

BD Program Evaluation. An evaluation of the 2012-14 BD cohort was conducted by an  external evaluator. The  overall goal of the evaluation was to examine the experiences of current  BD fellowship participants to understand the factors that  contribute to the success of the students as well as those that impede  their progress. Some of these themes that emerged include 1) science predisposition, 2) points of transition, 3) supporting/mentoring, 4) presence of a "like-type" community and 5) program components. Some new  findings also emerged such as the need for additional study skills and time managment workshops as well as workshops that connect Fellows to STEM industry professionals. Based on the findings of  this exploratory study, eight recommendations were offered to assist the  BD program with assessing the needs of the students and the programÆs  initiatives for next year.  

BD Information Dissemination. During the 2012-2014 project, the BD Project Directors disseminated  information on the BD Program on the LSAMP website and the BD Cohort  listerv.

Broader Impacts: Many LSAMP students are members of  groups that traditionally have been underrepresented in STEM fields. This BD activity increased the number of such students in the pipeline  to earn doctoral degrees in these fields. Additionally, activities were  planned to provide the participants with information about a variety of  STEM career options and careers in the professoriate.

BD Program Accomplishments.  Since 2006, UMD received four BD grants (2006, 2008, 2010 and 2012) with a  total of 65 students being awarded fellowships. Since the first cohort  began in 2006, 11 students have earned doctoral degrees, 20 students  have earned masterÆs degrees and 28 students are currently enrolled in a  masterÆs or doctoral program.
